title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the short title. It includes increased expensing for small businesses. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" increases expensing limits for small businesses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The dollar limitation for aggregate costs is set at $75,000, with a phaseout threshold of $325,000. Certain computer software is also included as section 179 property. Section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the limitation from $200,000 to $325,000. Section 179 property now includes tangible property, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for business use. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the limitation on Section 179 property from $200,000 to $325,000. This includes tangible property, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for business use. Additionally, there are inflation adjustments for dollar amounts in certain taxable years. Inflation adjustments for dollar amounts in taxable years after 2003 involve increasing amounts based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded accordingly. In taxable years after 2003, dollar amounts are adjusted for inflation based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000. Revocation of an election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) of the Code is allowed. The taxpayer can revoke an election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) of the Code for any property, and once revoked, it is irrevocable. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. NEUTRAL COST RECOVERY DEPRECIATION ADJUSTMENT FOR CERTAIN PROPERTY PLACED IN SERVICE AFTER DECEMBER 31, 2003. Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for a deduction adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. This adjustment allows for a 150 percent deduction instead of the usual 200 percent for eligible property under section 179. The amendment to Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction adjustment for eligible property, reducing the deduction from 200 percent to 150 percent for property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is determined for each taxable year to calculate the deduction amount. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is calculated for eligible property each taxable year by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter the property was placed in service by the deflator for the same quarter. The applicable cost recovery ratio for eligible property each taxable year is calculated by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter the property was placed in service by the deflator for the same quarter, and then multiplying the result by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years in the period. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for certain property is determined without regard to specific rules, and it shall never be less than 1. It is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The neutral cost recovery ratio is determined without considering certain rules. The gross domestic product deflator is used for calculations. Taxpayers can elect not to apply this subsection to their property, and once the election is made, it is irrevocable. Churning transactions are exempt from this subsection under specific conditions. The subsection exempts churning transactions under certain conditions. The additional deduction does not affect property basis or recapture. The text discusses the treatment of pass-thru entities for depreciation purposes and the minimum tax treatment for property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The new subparagraph allows for the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003, affecting the deduction allowable for such property in subsequent taxable years. The new subparagraph allows for the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003, affecting the deduction allowable for such property in subsequent taxable years. Subparagraph (C) of section 56(g)(4) is also amended to exclude the additional deduction allowed by section 168(k). Coordination with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles is addressed in section 280F(a)(1)(B) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2003, regarding the coordination with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles under section 280F(a)(1)(B) of the Code.
